facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 638 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal No. 638 of 1952.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated May 21, 1957 of the Assam High Court in First Appeal No. 7 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated May 21, 1957 of the Assam High Court in First Appeal No. 7, of 1962.

facts.text: Appellants carried on business at Raha in Nowgong District.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants carrying on business at Raha in Nowgong District had dealings with the respondents, carrying on business at Gauhati.

facts.text: Respondents carried on business at Gauhati.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants carrying on business at Raha in Nowgong District had dealings with the respondents, carrying on business at Gauhati.

facts.text: Appellants were indebted to respondents in a sum of Rs. 9,447-4-9.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of the said dealings, the appellants were indebted to the respondents in a sum of Rs. 9,447-4-9.

facts.text: Appellants sent to respondents a cheque for Rs. 9,461-4-0 dated August 31, 1948 to satisfy dues.

anchor.surface_text: In order to satisfy the dues of the respondents, the appellants sent to the respondents a cheque for Rs. 9,461-4-0 dated August 31, 1948.

facts.text: Cheque drawn by Messrs. Nathuram Jaidayal of Sibsagar on Tripura Modern Bank, Sibsagar Branch, in favour of appellants, endorsed to respondents.

anchor.surface_text: The cheque was drawn by a third party, Messrs. Nathuram Jaidayal of Sibsagar on the Tripura Modern Bank, Sibsagar Branch, in favour of the appellants, who endorsed it to the respondents.

facts.text: On September 4, 1948, respondents sent the cheque to Calcutta Commercial Bank, Gauhati for collection.

anchor.surface_text: On September 4, 1948, the respondents sent the cheque to their bankers, the Calcutta Commercial Bank, Gauhati for collection.

facts.text: On September 4, 1948, Calcutta Commercial Bank, Gauhati sent the cheque to Tripura Modern Bank, Sibsagar for encashment.

anchor.surface_text: On the same day, the Calcutta Commercial Bank, Gauhati sent the cheque to the Tripura Modern Bank, Sibsagar for encashment.

facts.text: Tripura Modern Bank, Sibsagar debited accounts of Messrs. Nathuram Jaidayal with Rs. 9,461-4-0.

anchor.surface_text: The Tripura Modern Bank, Sibsagar debited the accounts of their constituents. Messrs Nathuram Jaidayal with the sum of Rs. 9,461-4-0,

facts.text: Tripura Modern Bank deducted Rs. 6-4-0 commission and sent draft for Rs. 9,435 dated September 14, 1948 to Calcutta Commercial Bank, Gauhati.

anchor.surface_text: and after deducting Rs. 6-4-0 on account of commission charges, sent to the Calcutta Commercial Bank, Gauhati a draft for Rs. 9,435/-dated September 14, 1948 towards payment of the cheque.

facts.text: Draft drawn by Tripura Modern Bank, Sibsagar on its Calcutta Head Office, marked current for three months.

anchor.surface_text: The draft was drawn by the Tripura Modern Bank, Sibsagar on its Calcutta Head Office, and was marked current for three months from the date of the issue.

facts.text: Calcutta Commercial Bank, Gauhati sent the draft to Head Office at Calcutta for collection but never presented it and made no attempts to collect.

anchor.surface_text: On receipt of the draft, the Calcutta Commercial Bank, Gauhati sent it to their Head Office at Calcutta for collection. But the Calcutta Commercial Bank never presented the draft to the Tripura Modern Bank, and made no attempts to collect the amount of the draft.

facts.text: Respondents informed appellants that cash payment for the cheque had not been received.

anchor.surface_text: In the meantime, the respondents wrote to the appellants informing them that cash payment for the cheque has not been received,

facts.text: On September 18, 1948, appellants replied asking respondents to get back the cheque, but cheque was never returned.

anchor.surface_text: and on September 18, 1948 the appellants replied asking the respondents to get back the cheque. But the cheque was never returned to the respondents.

facts.text: On September 17, 1948, Calcutta Commercial Bank closed its business and was subsequently ordered to be wound up.

anchor.surface_text: On September 17, 1948, the Calcutta Commercial Bank closed its business, and subsequently, it was ordered to be wound up.

facts.text: On October 16, 1948, Tripura Modern Bank closed its business and entered into a scheme of arrangement with creditors.

anchor.surface_text: On October 16, 1948, the Tripura Modern Bank also closed its business. and in view of its inability to pay its dues, was compelled to enter into a scheme of arrangement with its creditors.

facts.text: On November 19, 1948, respondents requested Tripura Modern Bank to pay the amount of the draft to them and not to Calcutta Commercial Bank. No payment was made.

anchor.surface_text: On November 19, 1948, the respondents requested the Tripura Modern Bank to pay the amount of the draft to them and not to the Calcutta Commercial Bank. But no payment was made by the Tripura Modern Bank either to the respondents or to the Calcutta Commercial Bank.

facts.text: On March 8, 1949, respondents instituted the suit claiming payment of dues from appellants as cheque was conditional payment and not cashed.

anchor.surface_text: On March 8, 1949, the respondents instituted the suit, out of which the appeal arises, claiming payment of their dues from the appellants on the footing that the cheque dated August 31, 1948 was received by the respondents as a conditional payment, and as the cheque was not cashed,

facts.text: Subordinate Judge, Lower Assam District, dismissed the suit.

anchor.surface_text: The Subordinate Judge, Lower Assam District, dismissed the suit.

facts.text: Assam High Court reversed the judgment and decreed the suit.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, the High Court reversed the judgment appealed from, and decreed the suit.

facts.text: Appellants appeal to Supreme Court by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants now appeal to this Court by special leave.

facts.text: High Court held that respondents received cheque as conditional payment.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rightly held that the respondents originally received the cheque dated August 31, 1948 as a conditional payment of their dues,

facts.text: Supreme Court held that due to laches of respondents in collection of draft and prejudice to appellants, respondents deemed to have retained draft as absolute payment, original debt discharged.

anchor.surface_text: But we think that having regard to the laches of the respondents in the collection of the draft and the consequential prejudice to the appellants, the respondents must be deemed to have retained the draft as absolute payment of the cheque, and on the payment of the cheque, the original debt stood discharged.

facts.text: Draft would have been paid if presented before October 16, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: P.W. 3 admitted that had the draft been presented for payment to the Tripura Modern Bank before October 16, 1948, it would have been paid on presentation,

facts.text: PW3 stated draft sent by registered post to head office but returned undelivered as head office closed.

anchor.surface_text: P.W. 3, an employee of the Calcutta Commercial Bank, said that the draft, was sent by the Gauhati Office of the Bank to its head office by registered post, but the head office had closed its business and the draft came back to the Gauhati office undelivered.

facts.text: Appellants contended that collecting agents accepted demand draft as absolute payment.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Chatterjee also contended that the respondents collecting agents must be deemed to have accepted the demand draft on September 14, 1948 as absolute payment of the cheque,

facts.text: In Mudholkar J judgment, first ground: plaintiffs-respondents accepted draft as payment of cheque, subsequent dishonor does not revive liability.

anchor.surface_text: the first of which was that the plaintiffs- respondents had accepted the draft for Rs. 9,455/- dated September 14, 1948 drawn by the Tripura Modern Bank, Sibsagar on its Head Office at Calcutta in payment of the cheque for Rs. 9,461-4-0

anchor.surface_text: In Chitty on Contracts, 22nd Edn., Art. 1079, the law is stated thus Where a negotiable instrument, upon which the debtor is number primarily liable, is accepted by the creditor as companyditional payment, he is bound to do all that a holder of such an instrument may do in order to get payment thus it is his duty to present a cheque within a reasonable time, and if he fails to do. so, and the debtor is thereby prejudiced, the creditor is guilty of laches

issues.text: Whether the respondents originally received the cheque dated August 31, 1948 as a conditional payment of their dues, such that the original debt would revive on non-payment of the cheque

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rightly held that the respondents originally received the cheque dated August 31, 1948 as a conditional payment of their dues, and if nothing else happened, the original debt Would have revived on non- payment of the cheque.

issues.text: Whether having regard to the laches of the respondents in the collection of the draft and the consequential prejudice to the appellants, the respondents must be deemed to have retained the draft as absolute payment of the cheque, discharging the original debt

arguments.claim: Creditor accepting negotiable instrument as conditional payment bound to present cheque within reasonable time; failure causing prejudice is laches, amounts to payment of debt.

anchor.surface_text: In Chitty on Contracts, 22nd Edn., Art. 1079, the law is stated thus Where a negotiable instrument, upon which the debtor is not primarily liable, is accepted by the creditor as conditional payment, he is bound to do all that a holder of such an instrument may do in order to get payment thus it is his duty to present a cheque within a reasonable time, and if he fails to do.

arguments.claim: If debtor gives order on banker and creditor accepts but keeps unreasonable time before presenting and banker insolvent, debtor discharged due to laches.

anchor.surface_text: In Addisons Treatise on the Law of Contracts, 11th Edn., p. 156, it is stated-- If the debtor makes an order upon his banker for payment of the amount of the debt, and the creditor accepts it, and keeps it in his hands an unreasonable time before presenting it for payment, and the banker becomes insolvent, the debtor is discharged on account of the laches of the creditor.

arguments.claim: Creditor taking cheque from debtor's agent bound to present within reasonable time; delay altering debtor's position discharges debtor.

anchor.surface_text: In Hopkins v. Ware, it was held that a creditor who takes from his debtors agent on account of the debt the cheque of the agent, is bound to present it for payment within a reasonable time and if he fails to do so and by his delay alters for the worse the position of the debtor, the debtor is discharged,

arguments.claim: Creditor accepting bill or draft on third person, holding unreasonable time before demanding money, and drawer insolvent, creditor's own loss.

anchor.surface_text: In the old case of Chamberlain v. Delarive it was held that if a creditor accepting a bill or draft of his debtor upon a third person holds it an unreasonable time before he demands the money, and the person upon whom it is drawn becomes insolvent, it is the creditors own loss,

arguments.claim: Respondents owed duty to present draft within reasonable time; instead kept it without attempts to cash.

anchor.surface_text: The draft could be presented for payment at any time during the period of three months from the date of its issue. Instead of presenting the draft for payment, the respondents collecting agents kept it in their hands, and made no attempts to cash it.

arguments.claim: Draft sent by registered post but returned undelivered as head office closed; closure not excuse for not presenting within reasonable time.

holdings.text: The failure of the respondents and their agents to cash the draft within a reasonable time altered the position of the appellants for the worse, and caused prejudice to them. anchor.surface_text: In Hobkins v. Ware 1 , it was held that a creditor who takes from his debtors agent on account of the debt the cheque of the agent, is bound to present it for payment within a reasonable time and if he fails to do so and by his delay alters for the worse the position of the debtor, the debtor is discharged, although he was number a party to the cheque.
